prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so the user is asking whether the author of this situation is in the wrong. Let me read through the details again to make sure I understand.

The author is in a relationship where they live together with their girlfriend. He mentions that she only works part-time, and he pays all the rent and bills. He didn't mind that until last night when they went to get takeout. He left his wallet at work, so he asked her to pay for it. She had a bad attitude, seeming disgusted and put out. The takeout was under $40. Now, he's thinking about making her start paying some bills because of this one incident, even though he knows she can't pay a lot. He feels it's time for her to carry her weight, just out of principal.

First, I need to consider the context. The girlfriend works part-time, which might mean her income is lower. The author has been covering all expenses, and this is a sudden change he's considering based on a single event. The key points here are the financial contributions in the relationship and the reaction to the incident.

In relationships, especially when cohabiting, financial responsibilities can be a sensitive topic. The author's frustration is understandable if he's been shouldering all costs, but deciding to make her pay after one incident might not be fair. The girlfriend's reaction could have been due to surprise or stress, but the author is generalizing her behavior from a single event. That seems like an overreaction. 

Also, the author is implying that she should pay more out of principal, not necessarily because she can contribute more financially. If her income is low, expecting her to pay a significant portion of the bills might be unrealistic. The incident was minor, under $40, so holding it against her for a major financial change seems harsh. 

Possible factors to consider: communication. The author might be upset about the incident, but maybe there's a bigger issue about how they split expenses. Instead of a sudden shift after one event, discussing a fair way to split bills based on their incomes might be better. The girlfriend's attitude might indicate something else, like feeling taken advantage of, but the author is reacting out of anger without addressing the underlying issues.

So, based on this, the author is in the wrong because he's making a significant financial change due to a single, perhaps isolated incident, and not considering the girlfriend's financial situation. It's also about the approach—using principal as a reason without a realistic expectation of her ability to pay. The right approach would be to have an open conversation rather than a punitive measure.
